SEMICONDUCTOR

A semiconductor is a material which has an electrical conductivity intermediate in value between that of pure metal and that of a good insulator, e.g. silicon and germanium. Unlike pure metals, the conductivity of semiconductors increases with temperature. On the other hand, the resistance of pure metals increases with temperature while the reverse is the case with semiconductors. (understand this well).

Current is carried through a semiconductor through electrons and holes. The hole movement is equivalent to the movement of a positive charge. At room temperature there is equal number of electrons and hole. 

There are two types of semiconductors, the p-type and the n-type. The p-type has more holes than electron, while the n-type has more electrons than holes. The p-n junction diode consist of a p-type and n-type semiconductor in contact. The p-n junction diode acts like rectifier like thermionic diode.

Example

When a pentavalent impurity is added to a pure semiconductor, it becomes

A. a p-type semiconductor, B. an n-type semiconductor, C. an insulator, D. an intrinsic semiconductor.

B. an n-type semiconductor is produced when a pentavalent impurity is added to a pure semiconductor
